Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:The role of nuclear biomechanics during cell migration in 3-D environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Lammerdng. Jan
Proposal ID: 1254846

Intellectual Merits: While cell migration on 2-dimensional (2-D) substrates has been studied for many decades, the physical challenges cells face when moving in 3-D environments are only beginning to emerge now. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that deformation of the large and stiff nucleus presents a rate-limiting step during migration through tight constriction encountered in 3-D environments such as extracellular matrixes or during intra- or extravasation. This project will address to what extent the deformability of the nucleus governs the transit of cells through narrow constrictions by monitoring cells as they migrate through microfluidic channels with defined constrictions while visualizing subcellular deformations and transit efficiency. In addition, ablation of cytoskeletal filaments with femtosecond laser pulses as cells pass through narrow constrictions will be used to determine whether the nucleus is being pulled or pushed by the cytoskeleton to overcome its resistance when squeezing through constrictions smaller than the size of the nucleus. Complementing these experiments, molecular sensors engineered from modified nuclear envelope proteins that report tensile forces and localized compression at the nuclear envelope by changes in fluorescence intensity or fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) efficiency will be applied to cells during 3-D migration to quantify the cytoskeletal forces acting on the nucleus during 3-D migration and visualize their distribution along the nuclear periphery.

Broader Impact:
The research activities will be complemented with a comprehensive education and outreach program that builds on simplified models of the proposed research to introduce middle and high school students to biomedical engineering, with the goal of increasing participation of female students in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) subjects. Tapioca pearls, the key ingredient of the popular bubble tea, will be used as safe, easily accessible, and inexpensive stand-in for biological cells, while simple 'millifluidic' devices replace technically demanding microfluidics designs to probe cellular biomechanics. These 'tapioca millifluidics' experiments, along with accompanying lectures, will be introduced to students from underserved middle and high schools as part of existing and novel outreach programs at Cornell University that target high school girls and underrepresented minorities to provide them with hands-on experiences in biomedical engineering to boost confidence, meet role models, and overcome gender stereotypes. An additional education component is the creation of an online portal for self-directed learning to address the challenge of teaching interdisciplinary biomedical engineering courses to students with diverse academic backgrounds.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cells moving through the human body frequently have to pass through tight spaces that are substantially smaller than the size of the cell. Examples include immune cells that exit blood vessels to enter sites of infections, or metastatic cancer cells spreading from the primary tumor to invade other tissues. The research performed in this project has revealed that during cell migration in such confined environments, the deformability of the cell nucleus, which is the largest and stiffest cellular organelle, presents a physical limit for the ability of cells to transit through microscopic spaces. Our findings provide an explanation for the unique structure of the nuclei of some specialized immune cells (neutrophils) that are particularly adept at moving through tissues, and also point to specific adaptations of highly invasive tumor cells. Furthermore, we have demonstrated that the physical stress exerted on the nucleus during confined migration can result in damage to the cell nucleus and the genetic material inside, which could result in genomic abnormalities. Our studies have produced further insights into the biophysical mechanisms by which cells move their nuclei through tight spaces, indicating that they can both pull and push on the nucleus.  Taken together, the research supported through this project has led to an improved understanding of how cells move through confined tissue spaces, with important implications in both physiological and pathological settings.

This project has also produced several novel experimental models that will benefit the broader research community. For example, we have developed novel microfluidic devices that mimic the physical spaces cells must navigate inside tissues and that allow imaging cell migration through such environments at high spatial and temporal resolution (Figure 1). In addition, we have developed several experimental assays to probe the mechanical properties of cells and their nuclei. These devices and assays have already been made available to a large number of other researchers. In addition, we have carried out substantial outreach efforts to high school and college students to introduce them to science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM), with a particularly emphasis on increasing the participation of female students in STEM disciplines. These outreach efforts have taken advantage of custom-developed scaled-up and safe-to-use models of our experimental systems, thereby enabling the students to obtains hands-on experiences with biomedical research.


Last Modified: 09/27/2020
Modified by: Jan Lammerding

  • Time-lapse image sequence of a breast cancer cell migrating through a collagen-coated microfluidic device with a 2 by 5 micrometer constriction. The cell nucleus is labeled in green, the cell body (actin cytoskeleton) in red. Scale bar: 20 micrometer
    Jeremy Keys, Lammerding Lab (Cornell University)
    Copyrighted
    Jan Lammerding
    Figure 1
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Cells moving through the human body frequently have to pass through tight spaces that are substantially smaller than the size of the cell. Examples include immune cells that exit blood vessels to enter sites of infections, or metastatic cancer cells spreading from the primary tumor to invade other tissues. The research performed in this project has revealed that during cell migration in such confined environments, the deformability of the cell nucleus, which is the largest and stiffest cellular organelle, presents a physical limit for the ability of cells to transit through microscopic spaces. Our findings provide an explanation for the unique structure of the nuclei of some specialized immune cells (neutrophils) that are particularly adept at moving through tissues, and also point to specific adaptations of highly invasive tumor cells. Furthermore, we have demonstrated that the physical stress exerted on the nucleus during confined migration can result in damage to the cell nucleus and the genetic material inside, which could result in genomic abnormalities. Our studies have produced further insights into the biophysical mechanisms by which cells move their nuclei through tight spaces, indicating that they can both pull and push on the nucleus. Taken together, the research supported through this project has led to an improved understanding of how cells move through confined tissue spaces, with important implications in both physiological and pathological settings. This project has also produced several novel experimental models that will benefit the broader research community. For example, we have developed novel microfluidic devices that mimic the physical spaces cells must navigate inside tissues and that allow imaging cell migration through such environments at high spatial and temporal resolution (Figure 1). In addition, we have developed several experimental assays to probe the mechanical properties of cells and their nuclei. These devices and assays have already been made available to a large number of other researchers. In addition, we have carried out substantial outreach efforts to high school and college students to introduce them to science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM), with a particularly emphasis on increasing the participation of female students in STEM disciplines. These outreach efforts have taken advantage of custom-developed scaled-up and safe-to-use models of our experimental systems, thereby enabling the students to obtains hands-on experiences with biomedical research.
